content: lemon peel stitch square by jen spears we re going to turn stitch practice squares into something useful it s a fantastic way to practice a new stitch *and* have a practical finished project if you don t want fingerless mitts use cotton yarn and use your practice square as a dishcloth or seam two together to make a potholder for one square i used size h/5mm hook about 70 yards worsted per square i used hobbii rainbow 8/8 or hobbii friends 8/8 you ll also need a tapestry needle and a ruler or tape measure crochet tutorials found on the crocheters of awesome blog including finding the back bump of your chain for the first row single_crochet and double_crochet all tutorials found at www crochetersofawesome blogspot com for these squares we re going to use the lemon peel stitch it is created by alternating single crochet and double_crochet stitches to create a bumpy texture like lemon peel lemon peel stitch square - step by step chain 27 to adjust size add or subtract in multiples of 2 stitches row 1 single_crochet single_crochet into the back ridge/bump of the second chain from hook double_crochet double_crochet into the next chain alternate single_crochet and double_crochet in each remaining chain chain 1 ch1 turn 26 st 13 single_crochet 13 double_crochet when you insert your hook into the right place this is how it will look from the top and from the bottom before you start row 2 ch1 to give room to turn your work and keep it flat this is what the end of the row looks like before you turn and after you turn the first stitch in row 2 will go into the second teardrop shaped pair of loops the first is left open for turning room row 2 *single_crochet double_crochet* *repeat* across row ch1 turn 26 st each row will start with single_crochet and end with double_crochet ch1 turn repeat row 2 to your preferred measurement 26 st leave a long end to use for seaming about 4 times the width of your square and cut yarn notes in every row you ll work an single_crochet into the top of the double_crochet below and a double_crochet into the top of every single_crochet below here is what the single_crochet and the double_crochet in the row below look like the double_crochet has an extra loop going across the top half of the stitch which pushes the v shaped lines at the bottom of the stitch down it can be difficult to see which loops you should insert your hook under so if you get lost tilt the top edge towards you and look at the row below from that angle make your stitch under the two loops that make a teardrop shape my work is 8 inches wide and i will work until it is also 8 inches tall if it is within a half inch width to length leave it be if it is slightly more do another row or
